text: the climate conference in Copenhagen is
in its second week and readers from all
over the world have been sending
questions to our website The Times is
Andy Revkin our environmental writer
who's been covering this issue for many
many years is there in Copenhagen and
has been there from a start he's here
with us now to answer some of those
questions Andy we have a question from
daniel lippman in washington DC he wants
to know why are European governments and
European citizens more dedicated to
cutting carbon emissions faster and
deeper than most Americans and the
American government well Europe for
decades actually pretty much since world
war at the end of World War two it's
been much more thrifty with energy
generally the average European emits
about half as much carbon dioxide is the
average American for an American through
the course of the year it's about 20
tons a year in Europe typically it's
about 10 so some of thats just kind of
come naturally because fuel prices are
higher resources are scarce er they also
when the Kyoto Protocol the climate
treaty that came into effect several
years ago Europe signed on to that we
didn't one reason they had an easier
time is because of some things that were
happening in Europe just historically
the United Kingdom moved away from coal
and toward natural gas the big natural
gas finds in the North Sea and Germany
when it absorbed East Germany they
turned off a lot of inefficient old
factories and that gave them a big gain
under the under the system as well so
it's a kind of a mixture of of habit
when you go into a building here
anywhere here all the hallway lights are
on timers or you know motion activated
things we in the States just aren't
attuned to this yet like that Annie
these questions are coming from people
all over the world and here's one from
Germany someone called old stone 50 he
wants to know what role does world
population size play in global warming
and if it plays a role is there some way
in which population control ought to be
part of the climate discussion well yeah
you know the all the texts that are
being batted around here in Copenhagen
in these treaty talks the word
population I have
to see and any one of these texts it's a
really tricky situation when you get
into global negotiations to talk about
population growth for a lot of reasons
I've written a lot about it and I've
gotten hammered when I've mentioned
population in a climate context that's
when Rush Limbaugh not long ago
suggested I kill myself to save the
planet if I thought there were too many
people why not start with me so it's one
of these hot button issues and it's not
an it's it's fascinating you know
sub-saharan Africa is probably going to
double its population in the next 50
years and that's a big deal but the
United States is going to add probably
100 million new Americans in the next 40
40 years every one of those is is what
you might call a super emitter you know
again we have very high rates of
emissions per person that's mostly
through immigration but the snow the
atmosphere doesn't care if it's a baby
or for someone moving to a country if
you create a lot more high polluting
people that's that's an issue so
population is implicitly part of the
calculation of how much of these gases
go up and how warn the world gets now
and I have two questions related to
protesters so let me give you the first
one Thomas from somewhere in the US he
describes himself he wants to know who's
financing the travel and accommodations
for the tens of thousands of activists
in Copenhagen what's their political
affiliation and especially what
organized groups do the black-clad shock
troops belong to I think it's a little
hard to determine in some cases those
those the black masks as they were
called my guess is from what I
understand they're mostly you know
people from the region and remember
Europe is a small place you just hop on
a train or a bus or hitch a ride and you
get somewhere I don't get the impression
they're a well-financed bunch they had
homemade shields and and paint bombs not
anything more sophisticated than that
the the mass of protesters that were
here is everything from college kids in
the United States I met a young man on
the train last night leaving the protest
and he had taken the bus from Paris you
know he just kind of hopped on the bus
and felt he wanted to be here so he
didn't he clearly was not part of any
organized effort there was there also
counter protesters as we as I reported
on earth with my
video report there were some
libertarians you know anti-regulatory
folks who were making a strong statement
in the plaza as well I don't know who
paid their way but they were there as
well so it's kind of a you know clearly
the dominant mass there was where people
who were very eager to attack greenhouse
gas emissions or to order some of them
had very different agendas as well that
were somehow tangentially related to
this issue now another question on
another subject from BR one in New York
City he writes I and many others are
concerned that any reforms that come out
of Copenhagen will be toothless rules
that will be gained by governments and
industry with no actual changes ever
happening respond to that that question
came from someone who is spot-on on
something there there is a concern among
those who really are worried about the
build up of these gases that a lot of
this is on paper and what you want to
see is what would really happen on the
ground the 1997 Kyoto Protocol bound a
certain number of countries to curb
emissions but it turned out that it was
pretty hard to do that all on your own
your own soil in Europe and in Japan so
quite often they would buy offsets what
are called offsets and it's still
unclear how well they're going to meet
their targets when those deadlines are
hit in a couple of years and then the
rest of the world of course has just
seen emissions rise pretty relentlessly
with a little downward tick because of
the recession the last year or two
question from another skeptic bill in
washington wants to know how do green
energy funds go to countries with a
hundred years of endemic corruption and
not get siphoned off to make a few
people rich this is a big issue here
actually developing countries are
demanding a lot of funds that would flow
from industrialized countries to help
them divert from just using fossil fuels
to help them get more energy options so
they can come out of poverty without you
know adding pollution of the atmosphere
and to help them adapt to climate risks
and how that money gets spent is is a
big issue for the people who were who
would be paying the bills the
industrialized countries want to have
clear what they call measurable
reportable and verifiable
action on emissions they want to be able
to check the books essentially so you
can't kind of fake it there are big
issues related to the forest projects
that are proposed here and and this is a
way that the the lack of governance or
the presence of corruption can cut in a
different way so if there's a lot of
money flowing to cut deforestation in
developing countries probably in most
cases the last place it would go are the
places the frontier zones in Indonesia
and a few places in the Amazon or South
Asia where the deforestation rates are
the worst you have the least governance
so you don't get money flowing there at
all so it can kind of cut both ways and
the Oscar in New Jersey asked this
according to a recent New York Times
report and the headline was new data
shows warming increased in last decade
The Times is saying there's been warming
in the last decade however an October
article in the Sun in the journal
Science reports that there hasn't been
warming in a decade so who's right well
I think what you're hearing there is
confusion about the difference between
climate change and climate variability
climate change is when the system is
changing and there's a clear trend
underway for decades now that is hasn't
really diverted that has a lot of
Wiggles on the way to a warmer world so
that upward the upward graph has ups and
downs and people who have claimed that
the last decade has seen no warming are
starting from a year 1998 when we had a
very unusual hot year because of an El
Nino one of these big warm pools in the
Pacific that formed so it was
unnaturally it was actually naturally
hot that year but that created a high
peak in temperature and then we've had a
series of years that have been kind of
up and down sawtooth fashion and if you
just pick the year at the end in the
year at the beginning and say hey
there's no warming but if you use
statistics to analyze the whole long
trend over decades you see there clearly
is warming underway this is basically
the difference between weather and
climate and it's all about the long-term
picture the robustness of the picture of
a global warming caused by humans is in
in that century scale or half-century
scale not in the year
patterns Andy one more question related
to a little bit to science but a little
bit to coverage of the issue Steve Pesci
in California wants to know is the media
taking the stance that there's no need
for further debate about global warming
and if so isn't the nature of science to
have a hypothesis to test that
hypothesis and and create a new
hypothesis if necessary so how do you
square those two things science is
science is a journey and the best
coverage of global warming whether I'm
doing it or anybody else is is to convey
that the level of understanding is
always evolving and the robustness of
the picture of a human warmed world
right now has nothing to do with this
idea of the case being closed some
people have tried to portray it that way
it's way too simplistic it's a body of
evidence its broad and deep and it
points to rising risk with rising
temperature and rising emissions are
firmly understood to warm the planet
there's a lot of real questions though
and I've written about them sometimes I
get hammered by well all sides in this
debate people who think it's a
catastrophe those who think it's a hoax
find my coverage uncomfortable sometimes
perhaps because because I'm essentially
saying it's it's a more complicated
picture than that and what you have to
step do is step back and just understand
that this there's really nothing that
cuts from that long-term picture
especially when you just think of this
basically co2 is a greenhouse gas we we
know that it's part of why the planet is
warmer than is not a frozen ice ball and
adding more to the atmosphere will warm
the world there's even Michael Crichton
the the novelist who's passed away he
told me that and spoke about that in a
debate he doesn't disagree with it
didn't disagree with that and what you
can find dispute on real dispute not
manufactured dispute are very important
details that we still look at science
and hurricanes in 1988 when I first
wrote a big piece about global warming
scientists were telling me that they
expected a fifty percent rise in the
intensity of hurricanes in a warmed
world in this century now it's much more
nuanced it's a picture of probably more
intense storms getting stronger but
fewer storms overall so how do you it
not there that's not a no brainer it's
it's complicated and unfortunately that
doesn't fit very easily into a short
newspaper story or a short TV report so
what I hope is that readers kind of come
along for the long haul Andy thank you
so much for all the hard work that you
do and thanks for taking time out to
talk to us in Copenhagen we'll be back
again soon it's going to be getting cold
here in the next few days as you can see
two so that that'll generate some ironic
headlines I'm sure okay Andy take care
thanks
